findings.title: ST - Stops Transactions
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop the transactions for all users. The owner may take advantage of it by disabling the `isEnabled` variable.

findings.title: BC - Blacklists Addresses
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop addresses from transactions. The owner may take advantage of it by calling the `setBlacklist` function.

findings.title: PTRP - Potential Transfer Revert Propagation
findings.description: The contract sends funds to a `marketingWallet` as part of the transfer flow. This address can either be a wallet address or a contract. If the address belongs to a contract then it may revert from incoming payment. As a result, the error will propagate to the token’s contract and revert the transfer.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract is using variables that initialize them only in the constructor and are not mutated by other functions, but these variables are not defined as `immutable`. This can be improved for gas efficiency.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure they cannot be changed after being set, which decreases gas consumption of the corresponding transaction.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not adhere to the Solidity naming conventions, which can affect readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L05 - Unused State Variable
findings.description: An unused state variable is a state variable that is declared in the contract, but is never used in any of the contract's functions.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract. They are often used to notify external parties or clients about events that have occurred within the contract, such as the transfer of tokens or the completion of a task.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can make a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and can also increase the size of the contract and the cost of deploying and interacting with it.

findings.title: L16 - Validate Variable Setters
findings.description: The contract performs operations on variables configured by user-supplied input without proper checks for zero values, leading to potential problems during execution.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The contract does not lock the pragma version, which may lead to deployment with an unexpected version, producing vulnerabilities and undiscovered bugs.
